paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy in tumors?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 78 tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Preclinical arm testing intratumoral mRNA vaccine combined with anti-PD-L1 therapy in multiple murine tumor models

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 84 tumor-bearing mice pooled across matched controls
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Preclinical controls including vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle treatment groups

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human metastatic cohort (total)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment analyzed by vaccination status

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of metastatic ICI-treated patients with prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of metastatic ICI-treated patients without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients, introducing heterogeneity.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
